metadata.title: The Debate Drinking Game, with data science | by Anjali Shrivastava | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: The Debate Drinking Game, with data science
metadata.description: COVID-19 may have taken away our in-person debate watch parties, but it’s not stopping us from making a drinking game out of it! In my latest Youtube video, I used text mining techniques to develop…

all_paragraphs: COVID-19 may have taken away our in-person debate watch parties, but it’s not stopping us from making a drinking game out of it! In my latest Youtube video, I used text mining techniques to develop the ultimate data-driven drinking game rules for the upcoming Presidential debates. This post will walk you through exactly how I did that.

To start, I scraped the transcripts from campaign rallies, speeches, and any other events that have taken place in the last few weeks during which Biden or Trump (or both!) spoke. The full list of events I scraped can be seen in the Github repo for this project (see the “debates.csv” file).

I scraped the transcripts from rev.com (with their permission!) because it seemed to have the most exhaustive list of election 2020 events, and because the transcripts followed a standardized format, which made the scraping process easier. Here’s the function I used to scrape the transcripts:

The above function takes in two arguments — the URL to the transcript hosted on rev.com, and the “separator.” The “separator” refers to the character that’s used to denote who is speaking for each line; for most transcripts, the separator is “parenthesis” (eg. follows the format below).
Chris Wallace: (01:20)Good evening from the Health Education Campus of …

If the separator is not a parenthesis, I assume the regex expression I wrote assumes that it will be a colon (eg. follows the format below). You may have to modify the regex expressions depending on the transcript format.
Chris Wallace:Good evening from the Health Education Campus of …
The scraping function should return a dataframe that will look similar to this.
And once you’ve scraped all of the transcripts and concatenated the dataframes, we’re ready to move on to the text analysis!

Before we can begin the text analysis, we have to prepare the dataframes. Even though I scraped the transcripts from the same website, the naming conventions are inconsistent — Biden, for example, is sometimes referred to as “Joe Biden” and sometimes as “Vice President Joe Biden.”

I simply called pd.unique() on the “name” column of the dataframe so that I could see all of the name variations for each candidate. I then created a dictionary and used pd.replace() to replace all of these variations.
Then you can use the following “getSpeech” function and code to construct the corpus.

I then used the sklearn library to calculate the “tf-idf” statistic. Tf-Idf stands for Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency, and is a good measure for calculating the importance of a word. Not only does it consider frequency of a phrase, but it also devalues general phrases (eg. “thank you for that question…”) that might be said by both candidates — this ensures that the final phrases will be unique to Trump or Biden.
After calculating the tf-idf score on each object in the corpus and transforming the columns, you’ll get dataframes that might look like this:

Couple things to note: firstly, the script only identifies three or four word phrases (not including stop words). So words like “a,” “to,” and “the” are eliminated, which leaves some of these phrases unintelligeble. The full phrase of “don know don,” for example, is “I don’t know, I don’t.” And the full phrase of “running proud Democrat” is “running as a proud Democrat.”

Secondly, the fact that these phrases in the outputted dataframe are only three or four words long can present a number of problems. It means that crucial words may be left out — the full phrase of “going raise taxes” is actually “not going to raise taxes.” It also means that longer phrases may be broken into smaller chunks and are overrepresented in the table. One of Biden’s more common phrases is “God bless you all and may God protect the troops,” and this phrase was broken into rows 7, 9, 10 and 11 in the dataframe.

And finally, the tf-idf score does not indicate frequency — it is a combination of both frequency and uniqueness of a phrase. This is why the phrase “thank thank thank” shows up for both candidates — it is not unique, but was said so many times that it appears in the top 10 list. Still, it’s not at the top of the list even though it’s by far the most common. (And it’s worth noting that neither Biden nor Trump actually said this phrase. It’s referring to when the moderator says “Thank you Mr. President. Thank you President. Thank you ….” when a candidate goes over time).
To count how many times each phrase was said, you’ll have to manually look through your debates transcript CSV. Or at least, that’s what I did.
After cleaning replacing the stop words and reordering the phrases by frequency, we finally have the drinking game rules for the presidential debate on Thursday!
Confused about some of these phrases? I explain the context behind each of these phrases in my video, check it out!
Happy drinking! Please remember to drink (and vote!) responsibly.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Data Scientist at Thermo Fisher Scientific; I use data science and data visualization to answer questions I have about pop culture and Internet trends.
